questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023) RBS → 550 рН → 7.01 Na+ → 158 Urine glucose → 3+ Urine Ketone → +ve

options.label: A
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: C
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: D
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.correct_answer: A. Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urine is the most appropriate sample for the detection of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection using PCR, particularly in the neonatal period.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following medications taken during pregnancy is associated with the birth defect shown in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The facial defects, including cleft lip, observed in the child are characteristic of the teratogenic effects of isotretinoin. Isotretinoin is commonly used to treat severe acne but is highly teratogenic and should never be prescribed to women of reproductive age without ensuring they are not pregnant. The teratogenic effects of isotretinoin include craniofacial, cardiovascular, thymic, and central nervous system abnormalities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ferrous sulfate - This is an iron supplement and does not cause such birth defects.
  • • Option A. Ferrous sulfate
  • • Option C. Folic acid - This vitamin is actually recommended during pregnancy to prevent birth defects.
  • • Option C. Folic acid
  • • Option D. Metoclopramide - This antiemetic is not associated with the type of birth defects described.
  • • Option D. Metoclopramide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isotretinoin, used for severe acne treatment, is highly teratogenic and associated with severe birth defects such as craniofacial abnormalities, including cleft lip and palate.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child arrived with a history of fever, reddened and congested conjunctiva, along with skin exhibiting redness and peeling, as depicted in the provided images. A 2D echocardiogram revealed the presence of a coronary aneurysm. What constitutes the initial course of treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IVIG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Kawasaki disease, the initial course of treatment involves the administration of IVIG to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms and other complications.

questions.text: How long should a child be isolated after being diagnosed with bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.correct_answer: A. Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children with bacterial meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis or Haemophilus influenzae should be isolated for 24 hours after starting effective antibiotic therapy to prevent transmission.

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and poor feeding. On physical examination, the infant shows signs of tachypnea and tachycardia. An echocardiogram is performed, which reveals abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins, with no direct connection to the left atrium. Further evaluation indicates equal oxygen saturation in all four chambers of the heart. Which of the following congenital heart diseases is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.correct_answer: C. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) is a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, oxygenated blood from the lungs is redirected to the right atrium via connections to the superior vena cava, inferior vena cava, or both. This leads to a total mixing lesion where both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood mix completely, resulting in equal oxygen saturation in all four heart chambers. Blood reaches the left atrium and subsequently the left ventricle only through an atrial septal defect (ASD) or a patent foramen ovale, which shunts the mixed blood from the right atrium. This unique feature of TAPVC results in the characteristic finding of equal oxygen saturation in all cardiac chambers. TAPVC often presents with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and poor feeding in neonates and requires urgent surgical correction to restore normal pulmonary venous return.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Tetralogy of Fallot: This defect involves right ventricular outflow obstruction, a ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It results in cyanosis due to right-to-left shunting but does not cause equal saturation in all chambers.
  • • Option
  • • A) Tetralogy of Fallot:
  • • Option B) Transposition of the Great Arteries: This condition features parallel circulations with the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle, leading to severe cyanosis without equal saturation across all chambers.
  • • Option
  • • B) Transposition of the Great Arteries:
  • • Option D) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): A VSD allows for shunting of blood between the ventricles, but it does not cause equal oxygen saturation in all heart chambers.
  • • Option
  • • D) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TAPVC is a congenital heart defect that leads to equal oxygen saturation in all heart chambers due to the abnormal drainage of pulmonary veins into the right atrium, causing complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention are crucial to reestablish normal pulmonary venous return and prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.
  • ➤ The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:
  • ➤ For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413
  • ➤ Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:
  • ➤ The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer
  • ➤ Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hurler disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hurler disease, a form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1, presents with coarse facial features, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious nasal discharge, and is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase leading to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? (INICET NOV 2022) Airway and breathing IV Lorazepam Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone IV Fosphenytoine
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of status epilepticus in children should follow a systematic approach: securing the airway and ensuring breathing, administering a benzodiazepine, followed by fosphenytoin if seizures persist, and considering more potent agents like midazolam, propofol, or thiopentone if the status epilepticus is refractory to initial treatments.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? ( INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.

questions.text: A child presents with brown-colored urine and oliguria for the last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has 2+ proteinuria with >100 red cells/HPF and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PSGN

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency are indicative of PSGN.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II pneumocytes are crucial for surfactant production and alveolar stability, and their dysfunction or immaturity is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in neonates.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lumirubin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phototherapy converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys, making it an effective treatment for neonatal jaundice.

questions.text: Palivizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody. For which condition is it approved? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Palivizumab is specifically approved for the prevention and treatment of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections. It is particularly recommended for infants at high risk, such as those born prematurely or with conditions like congenital heart disease or chronic lung disease. Palivizumab works by providing passive immunity against RSV, reducing the severity and incidence of RSV-related illnesses.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Avian influenza - Palivizumab is not used for treating or preventing avian influenza.
  • • Option A. Avian influenza
  • • Option B. Parainfluenza - Palivizumab is not indicated for parainfluenza infections.
  • • Option B. Parainfluenza
  • • Option D. Coxsackie virus - Palivizumab is not used for Coxsackie virus infections.
  • • Option D. Coxsackie virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Palivizumab is approved for preventing and treating respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections in high-risk infants.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, apathy, and growth retardation due to a diet deficient in protein, often with a swollen belly and low serum protein levels.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position

options.label: C
options.text: The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle.

questions.correct_answer: D. Coagulopathy is not a contraindication.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Coagulopathy is not a contraindication.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coagulopathy is a contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the risk of bleeding and potential for serious complications, contrary to the incorrect statement provided. Always assess the patient’s coagulation status prior to performing an LP.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to OPD with jaundice and clay-colored stools. Lab work up reveals that the baby has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. A liver biopsy was done and shows periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Biliary atresia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An infant presenting with jaundice, clay-colored stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders has a high chance of catalase positive organisms causing infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic granulomatous disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic granulomatous disease is associated with a high risk of infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex, which impairs the killing of these organisms by phagocytes.

questions.text: Dr. Sunita, a medical officer in a rural health clinic, is tasked with ensuring the potency and safety of vaccines. She comes across several vaccine vials, each with a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) attached. The VVMs change color to indicate the cumulative exposure of the vaccine to heat, thus helping in determining the viability of the vaccine. She notices varying degrees of color changes across these VVMs. Given this scenario, which of the following choices correctly identifies which vaccine vials, based on the observed VVM color changes, should be considered safe for use? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.correct_answer: B. Vials 1 and 2 can be used
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vials 1 and 2 can be used

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: A 12-day-old neonate presents to the emergency department with increased irritability, poor feeding, and two episodes of seizures. Physical examination reveals a bulging fontanelle and lethargy. A lumbar puncture shows elevated white blood cells, high protein, and low glucose, suggestive of bacterial meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Neonatal meningitis is suspected in this clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus) , which is the leading cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis. It commonly affects both early-onset (within the first 72 hours of life) and late-onset neonatal infections.
  • • Neonatal meningitis
  • • Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus)
  • • Early-onset meningitis occurs within the first 72 hours of life and is mainly caused by Group B streptococci. In contrast, late-onset meningitis typically affects premature infants and is often caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci, such as Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Klebsiella.
  • • Early-onset meningitis
  • • late-onset meningitis
  • • Group B streptococci are the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis in full-term infants. Escherichia coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis in very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g), but it is less common than Group B streptococcus in full-term infants.
  • • Escherichia coli
  • • Neonates have immature cellular and humoral immunity, making them more susceptible to infections like meningitis and sepsis. Any infant aged 28 days or younger with fever or signs of sepsis should be promptly evaluated.
  • • Neonates have immature cellular and humoral immunity,
  • • The evaluation for sepsis includes a complete blood count (CBC), differential count, blood culture, urine culture, chest radiograph, and lumbar puncture. These tests help identify the causative organism and determine appropriate treatment.
  • • The evaluation for sepsis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Escherichia coli: Although a common cause of neonatal meningitis, especially in preterm and very low birth weight infants, it is less frequent in full-term infants compared to Group B streptococcus.
  • • Option
  • • A) Escherichia coli:
  • • Option C) Staphylococcus aureus: Typically associated with late-onset infections, particularly in hospitalized infants or those with central lines, but not as common in the early neonatal period.
  • • Option
  • • C) Staphylococcus aureus:
  • • Option D) Listeria monocytogenes: A less common cause of neonatal meningitis, often linked to maternal risk factors, such as consumption of contaminated food, and not the most likely in this scenario.
  • • Option
  • • D) Listeria monocytogenes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus) is the primary cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, particularly in full-term infants. Due to the neonate’s immature immune system, early recognition and management of these infections are crucial to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Downs syndrome? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Caudal regression syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the common clinical features and associated conditions of Down syndrome. Understand that hypothyroidism, hearing loss, and short stature are commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Be aware of the distinct features of other congenital conditions, such as caudal regression syndrome, that are not typically associated with Down syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 345
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 345

questions.text: An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? (INICET NOV 2022) Assess breathing Assess pulse Assess response Start compressions Bag and mask ventilation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3-1-2-4-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In BLS, the correct sequence of actions is crucial for effective management. Start by assessing response, followed by breathing and pulse, then initiate compressions and ventilation as needed.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with signs of malnutrition. The healthcare provider assesses the child’s nutritional status to determine if the child meets the criteria for severe acute malnutrition (SAM) according to WHO guidelines. Which of the following is not a criterion for diagnosing severe acute malnutrition?

options.label: B
options.text: Weight-for-length below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards

options.label: C
options.text: Weight-for-age below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards

questions.correct_answer: C. Weight-for-age below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO based on specific criteria that assess acute malnutrition, focusing primarily on body measurements that reflect wasting and the presence of edema.
  • • WHO Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):
  • • WHO Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):
  • • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm: This measurement reflects wasting and is commonly used in the field to quickly assess nutritional status in children aged 6 to 59 months. Weight-for-length (or height) below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards: This criterion specifically assesses the child’s weight relative to their height, indicating severe wasting. Presence of bipedal edema: Edema is a clinical sign of severe malnutrition, reflecting a more serious condition that is often associated with metabolic disturbances and increased risk of mortality. Weight-for-age below -3 SD: This is not a criterion for SAM. While weight-for-age can indicate undernutrition, it does not differentiate between stunting (chronic malnutrition) and wasting (acute malnutrition), making it less specific for diagnosing SAM.
  • • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm: This measurement reflects wasting and is commonly used in the field to quickly assess nutritional status in children aged 6 to 59 months.
  • • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm:
  • • Weight-for-length (or height) below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards: This criterion specifically assesses the child’s weight relative to their height, indicating severe wasting.
  • • Weight-for-length (or height) below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards:
  • • Presence of bipedal edema: Edema is a clinical sign of severe malnutrition, reflecting a more serious condition that is often associated with metabolic disturbances and increased risk of mortality.
  • • Presence of bipedal edema:
  • • Weight-for-age below -3 SD: This is not a criterion for SAM. While weight-for-age can indicate undernutrition, it does not differentiate between stunting (chronic malnutrition) and wasting (acute malnutrition), making it less specific for diagnosing SAM.
  • • Weight-for-age below -3 SD:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is diagnosed based on mid-upper arm circumference, weight-for-length or height below -3 SD, and the presence of bipedal edema. Weight-for-age is not used as a specific criterion for SAM because it does not accurately reflect acute malnutrition. Understanding these criteria is critical for identifying and managing malnutrition in pediatric populations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions as shown in the image. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. A. HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) T9

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mycobacteria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties. They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.
  • ➤ Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties.
  • ➤ They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing renal transplant management was started on cyclosporine as part of the immunosuppressive regimen. Within a few weeks, the patient begins to show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. The treating physician suspects drug-induced cholestasis and considers the involvement of a specific cellular transporter. Which cellular transporter is most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis in this patient
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. MRP2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRP2 (Multi-Drug Resistance-associated Protein 2) is the cellular transporter most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis due to its role in the efflux of bile salts and bilirubin into the bile canaliculus.

questions.text: A young female has history of a spontaneous abortion. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Uterine synechiae

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Secondary amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion and subsequent dilation and curettage (D&C) is typically due to intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome.
  • • Uterine Synechiae (Asherman Syndrome): This condition involves the formation of scar tissue within the uterine cavity, leading to amenorrhea or menstrual abnormalities. It commonly occurs after uterine surgeries like D&C. Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome. Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.
  • • Uterine Synechiae (Asherman Syndrome): This condition involves the formation of scar tissue within the uterine cavity, leading to amenorrhea or menstrual abnormalities. It commonly occurs after uterine surgeries like D&C. Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome. Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.
  • • Uterine Synechiae (Asherman Syndrome):
  • • Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome. Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.
  • • Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome.
  • • Diagnosis:
  • • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.
  • • Treatment:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Pituitary dysfunction: This would typically be associated with abnormal levels of pituitary hormones, including FSH. The normal FSH level (6 mIU/ml) suggests that pituitary function is intact.
  • • Option A. Pituitary dysfunction:
  • • Option B. Ovarian dysfunction: This condition would generally present with elevated or depressed levels of FSH and other ovarian hormones. The normal FSH level suggests that ovarian function is likely normal.
  • • Option B. Ovarian dysfunction:
  • • Option C. First pregnancy: In pregnancy, FSH levels are very low (<0.1 mIU/ml). The FSH level of 6 mIU/ml makes this an unlikely cause.
  • • Option C. First pregnancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secondary amenorrhea following a history of spontaneous abortion and D&C is usually due to intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome), diagnosed by hysteroscopy and treated with hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Substantial

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:
  • • A. Slight : A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.
  • • A. Slight
  • • B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.
  • • B. Fair:
  • • C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.
  • • C. Moderate:
  • • D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.
  • • D. Substantial:
  • • E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99
  • • E. Near Perfect agreement
  • • F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00
  • • F. Perfect agreement
  • • In this case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • ➤ High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug is not bactericidal? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Thioacetazone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug, which means it inhibits bacterial growth rather than killing the bacteria outright. In contrast, isoniazid, rifapentin, and kanamycin are all bactericidal drugs used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PGE1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) is used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates with congenital heart defects that require an open ductus arteriosus for adequate oxygenation and circulation.

questions.text: A newborn admitted to the NICU presents with microcephaly and hepatomegaly. The baby was born at 37 weeks gestation with low birth weight. A CT scan of the head shows nodular periventricular calcifications. The neonate also exhibits jaundice and thrombocytopenia. Based on these findings, congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is suspected. To confirm the diagnosis, which of the following samples is the most appropriate for detecting the virus using PCR?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Urine is the preferred sample for detecting congenital CMV infection using PCR because it typically contains a high viral load, making it a reliable option for early diagnosis. CMV can be detected using PCR or culture methods, and samples such as urine, saliva, or blood can be used. However, urine is often considered the best sample due to its sensitivity and ease of collection in neonates.
  • • Clinical Features of Congenital CMV Infection Include:
  • • Clinical Features of Congenital CMV Infection Include:
  • • Microcephaly Periventricular calcifications Hepatosplenomegaly Jaundice Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) Chorioretinitis Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) Blueberry-muffin-like rash Thrombocytopenia
  • • Microcephaly
  • • Periventricular calcifications
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • • Jaundice
  • • Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
  • • Chorioretinitis
  • • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  • • Blueberry-muffin-like rash
  • • Thrombocytopenia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Blood: Blood can be used but has a lower viral load compared to urine, making it less sensitive.
  • • Option
  • • A) Blood:
  • • Option C) Saliva: While saliva is another option, there is a risk of contamination from maternal CMV, which can cause false positives.
  • • Option
  • • C) Saliva:
  • • Option D) Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): CSF is used more for assessing CNS involvement and is not typically used for primary detection of CMV.
  • • Option
  • • D) Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urine is the most sensitive sample for detecting congenital CMV using PCR, making it the best option for early diagnosis in neonates. Early detection and management are crucial in reducing the risk of complications associated with CMV infection.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypopyon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.
  • ➤ Hypopyon

questions.text: Heller's operation is performed for: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Achalasia cardia, commonly referred to as achalasia, is a medical condition that affects the esophagus, specifically the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the muscles of the esophageal wall. This condition is characterized by the following features:
  • ➤ Failure of LES Relaxation: In achalasia, the LES, a muscular ring that separates the esophagus from the stomach, does not relax properly during swallowing. Normally, the LES should relax to allow food and liquids to pass into the stomach, but in achalasia, this relaxation is impaired. Incomplete Emptying of the Esophagus: Due to the dysfunctional LES, the esophagus is unable to empty food and liquids into the stomach efficiently. This leads to a gradual buildup of food and fluids in the esophagus, causing symptoms. Difficulty in Swallowing: The most prominent symptom of achalasia is dysphagia, which is difficulty in swallowing. Patients often experience a sensation of food getting stuck in the chest while eating and may need to drink fluids or change their body position to help food pass into the stomach. Regurgitation: As a result of the esophageal emptying problems, patients with achalasia may also experience regurgitation of undigested food, often occurring at night when lying down. Chest Pain: Some individuals with achalasia may experience chest pain or discomfort, often due to the accumulation of food and fluids in the esophagus.
  • ➤ Failure of LES Relaxation: In achalasia, the LES, a muscular ring that separates the esophagus from the stomach, does not relax properly during swallowing. Normally, the LES should relax to allow food and liquids to pass into the stomach, but in achalasia, this relaxation is impaired.
  • ➤ Failure of LES Relaxation:
  • ➤ Incomplete Emptying of the Esophagus: Due to the dysfunctional LES, the esophagus is unable to empty food and liquids into the stomach efficiently. This leads to a gradual buildup of food and fluids in the esophagus, causing symptoms.
  • ➤ Incomplete Emptying of the Esophagus:
  • ➤ Difficulty in Swallowing: The most prominent symptom of achalasia is dysphagia, which is difficulty in swallowing. Patients often experience a sensation of food getting stuck in the chest while eating and may need to drink fluids or change their body position to help food pass into the stomach.
  • ➤ Difficulty in Swallowing:
  • ➤ Regurgitation: As a result of the esophageal emptying problems, patients with achalasia may also experience regurgitation of undigested food, often occurring at night when lying down.
  • ➤ Regurgitation:
  • ➤ Chest Pain: Some individuals with achalasia may experience chest pain or discomfort, often due to the accumulation of food and fluids in the esophagus.
  • ➤ Chest Pain:
  • ➤ Achalasia is typically diagnosed through tests such as esophageal manometry, which measures the pressure within the esophagus, and barium swallow studies, which show the narrowing of the esophagus and the delayed emptying of contrast material.
  • ➤ Treatment options for achalasia include:
  • ➤ Heller Myotomy: This surgical procedure involves cutting the muscles of the LES to allow for improved passage of food and liquids into the stomach. It is the primary surgical treatment for achalasia. Pneumatic Dilation: In this non-surgical procedure, a balloon is inflated within the LES to stretch and disrupt the muscle fibers, making it easier for food to pass. Botulinum Toxin Injection: Injecting botulinum toxin directly into the LES can help relax the muscle temporarily. However, this treatment may need to be repeated periodically.
  • ➤ Heller Myotomy: This surgical procedure involves cutting the muscles of the LES to allow for improved passage of food and liquids into the stomach. It is the primary surgical treatment for achalasia.
  • ➤ Heller Myotomy:
  • ➤ Pneumatic Dilation: In this non-surgical procedure, a balloon is inflated within the LES to stretch and disrupt the muscle fibers, making it easier for food to pass.
  • ➤ Pneumatic Dilation:
  • ➤ Botulinum Toxin Injection: Injecting botulinum toxin directly into the LES can help relax the muscle temporarily. However, this treatment may need to be repeated periodically.
  • ➤ Botulinum Toxin Injection:
  • ➤ The choice of treatment depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the severity of the condition. Effective management of achalasia can alleviate symptoms and improve the quality of life for individuals with this disorder.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Putty kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney. This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography. Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.
  • ➤ Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney.
  • ➤ This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography.
  • ➤ Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle. Values and Interpretation: Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH)
  • • Values and Interpretation: Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Values and Interpretation:
  • • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
  • • Normal value:
  • • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
  • • Poor ovarian reserve:
  • • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL
  • • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome:
  • • Tests for ovarian reserve:
  • • Tests for ovarian reserve:
  • • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted. Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction. Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones. Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.
  • • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • • FSH levels:
  • • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • • Serum estradiol values:
  • • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • • Antral follicular count on ultrasound:
  • • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.
  • • Inhibin B:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.
  • • Option A. Luteal phase LH:
  • • Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.
  • • Option B. Post luteal phase LH:
  • • Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.
  • • Option C. FSH in the follicular phase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg435
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg435

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, previously vaccinated against rabies a year ago, was bitten by his vaccinated family pet dog on the toe, resulting in a bleeding wound. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this child? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

  • ➤ For a previously vaccinated individual bitten by a potentially rabid animal, the appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis is to administer 2 booster doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: Calculate the net filtration pressure across the GFM for a patient with the data given below? ( AIIMS May 2018) Glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient = 6 Glomerular hydrostatic pressure =45 Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure =20 Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure =10 Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure =0
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 15 mmHg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The net filtration pressure (NFP) in the glomerulus, essential for kidney filtration, is calculated based on the differences between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures inside and outside the glomerular capillaries. In this scenario, an NFP of 15 mmHg favors the formation of urine by pushing fluid out of blood vessels into the Bowman's capsule.

questions.text: A preterm infant is experiencing severe respiratory distress shortly after birth, characterized by tachypnea, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse ground-glass opacities consistent with a diagnosis of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Surfactant deficiency is suspected as a contributing factor. Which of the following marked structures in the image is primarily involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Type II pneumocytes, represented by Structure 2 in the image, are essential cells in the alveoli responsible for producing surfactant, a crucial substance that reduces surface tension within the alveoli and prevents their collapse during exhalation. These cells also play a significant role in alveolar repair by differentiating into type I pneumocytes when necessary. In respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), especially in premature infants, the type II pneumocytes are either immature or dysfunctional, leading to inadequate surfactant production. This deficiency results in increased surface tension, alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, and the characteristic respiratory distress seen in RDS.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Structure 1 (Type I pneumocytes): These cells form the primary lining of the alveoli, providing a thin barrier for gas exchange but do not produce surfactant.
  • • Option A) Structure
  • • 1 (Type I pneumocytes):
  • • Option C) Structure 3 (Capillary endothelial cells): These cells line the blood vessels within the alveolar walls and are involved in gas exchange but are not involved in surfactant production.
  • • Option C) Structure
  • • 3 (Capillary endothelial cells):
  • • Option D) Structure 4 (Macrophages ): These immune cells are responsible for removing debris and pathogens from the alveoli but do not play a direct role in surfactant production or the pathophysiology of RDS.
  • • Option D) Structure 4 (Macrophages
  • • ):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II pneumocytes produce surfactant, which is crucial in maintaining alveolar stability by reducing surface tension. In conditions like respiratory distress syndrome, damage or dysfunction of type II pneumocytes leads to surfactant deficiency, resulting in alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, and respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried female has come to the gynae OPD for cervical cancer vaccination. Which is preferred? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gardasil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for cervical cancer prevention. It is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that provides protection against four serotypes of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV): 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  • • HPV Serotypes Covered by Gardasil: 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts. 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.
  • • HPV Serotypes Covered by Gardasil: 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts. 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.
  • • HPV Serotypes Covered by Gardasil:
  • • 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts. 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.
  • • 6 and 11: These types are associated with anogenital warts.
  • • 6 and 11:
  • • 16 and 18: These types are linked to cervical cancer and other HPV-related cancers.
  • • 16 and 18:
  • • Gardasil is administered as an intramuscular injection with a recommended schedule of three doses (0, 2, and 6 months).
  • • Available HPV Vaccines:
  • • Available HPV Vaccines:
  • • Cervarix (Bivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 16 and 18. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18. Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent or HPV9): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent, covers serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  • • Cervarix (Bivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 16 and 18.
  • • Cervarix (Bivalent):
  • • Gardasil (Quadrivalent): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  • • Gardasil (Quadrivalent):
  • • Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent or HPV9): Covers HPV serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.
  • • Gardasil 9 (Nonavalent or HPV9):
  • • Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent, covers serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  • • Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Biovac: This is a vaccine for Hepatitis A, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.
  • • Option B. Biovac:
  • • Option C. Rabivac: This is a rabies vaccine for animals, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.
  • • Option C. Rabivac:
  • • Option D. Tvac: This is a tetanus vaccine, not related to HPV or cervical cancer.
  • • Option D. Tvac:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gardasil is the preferred vaccine for preventing cervical cancer and related HPV diseases, covering serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.who.int/teams/immunization-vaccines-and-biologicals/diseases/human-papillomavirus-vaccines-(HPV)
